questions.text: A 68 year old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty starting urination, weak urinary stream, and nocturia. He denies any pain during urination. What is the most likely term to describe his condition?
questions.solution:
URINARY SYMPTOMS DEFINITIONS

Storage Symptoms:

  • Frequency - the patient considers that they void too often during the day.
  • Nocturia - the individual wakes at night at least once to void.
  • Strangury - a sensation of constantly needing to void.

Typically, the patient describes having to stand/sit for long periods with the sensation that micturition is imminent.

  • Urgency - a sudden compelling desire to pass urine that is difficult to defer.
  • Urge incontinence - involuntary urinary leakage, often a large volume, immediately preceded by the sensation of urgency.
  • Nocturnal enuresis - involuntary loss of urine during sleep.

Voiding Symptoms:

  • Hesitancy - when an individual has difficulty initiating micturition, resulting in a delay in the onset of voiding.
  • Reduced urinary stream - usually reported compared with previous performance or in comparison with the performance of others.
  • Intermittency - when urine flow stops and starts, on one or more occasions.
  • Straining - the muscular effort used in order to initiate, maintain or improve the urinary stream.
  • Incomplete emptying - the sensation that, at the end of micturition, bladder fullness persists.
  • Post Micturition dribble - when involuntary loss of urine occurs immediately after the individual has finished passing urine.

Option A: Urgency: This term refers to a sudden and compelling need to urinate, which is not easily deferred. It is often seen in conditions causing bladder irritation, such as urinary tract infections.

Option B: Nocturia: This term describes the need to wake up one or more times at night to urinate. While the patient reports nocturia, it is not the primary concern in this scenario.

Option C: Hesitancy: This is the difficulty in starting or maintaining a steady urine stream, often associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or other causes of urinary obstruction. It best describes the patient's primary symptom.

Option D: Dysuria: This term indicates painful or difficult urination, often due to infection or inflammation. The patient does not report pain, ruling out dysuria.

Key Takeaway:

  • Hesitancy is typically caused by urinary tract obstruction, most commonly due to BPH in older men.
  • Urgency can indicate bladder irritation or overactivity.

questions.text: A 55 year old man presents with hematuria. An initial ultrasound suggests a bladder mass. What is the best diagnostic procedure to confirm this finding?
questions.solution:
Flexible Cystoscopy

Flexible cystoscopy is a procedure that uses a thin, flexible tube with a camera to visualise the interior of the bladder and urethra. It is a valuable diagnostic tool for evaluating hematuria, suspected bladder lesions, and other urinary tract conditions.

Indications

  • Hematuria: Blood in the urine (gross or microscopic)
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections
  • Suspicion of bladder cancer
  • Lower urinary tract symptoms

Advantages

  • Direct visualisation: Provides a clear view of the bladder and urethra.
  • Biopsy: Allows for tissue samples to be taken for further examination.
  • Diagnoses various conditions: Can diagnose tumours, stones, strictures, and other abnormalities.

Procedure

  • Rigid cystoscopy for Therapeutic Procedure: Performed under general anaesthesia.
  • Flexible cystoscopy For Diagnosis: Performed under local anaesthesia.

Complications

  • Infection
  • Bleeding
  • Transient discomfort or burning during urination

Option A: Intravenous urography While useful for evaluating the urinary tract, it is less effective for direct visualisation of bladder lesions.

Option B: Flexible cystoscopy allows direct visualisation of the bladder and any abnormal lesions, making it the diagnostic method of choice.

Option C: MRI is more suited for staging and assessing the extent of bladder cancer rather than initial diagnosis.

Option D: CT urogram provides a detailed view of the upper urinary tract and is helpful in detecting urothelial carcinomas but is not as definitive as direct visualisation with cystoscopy for bladder lesions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Flexible cystoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing bladder lesions.
  • It allows direct visualisation and biopsy, aiding in accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62 year old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) undergoes cystoscopy for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. The cystoscopic findings reveal bladder trabeculation and saccules. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Chronic bladder outlet Obstruction.

  • Bladder Trabeculation:
    • Thickening of the bladder wall, creating a ridged appearance due to chronic bladder outlet obstruction (e.g., BPH).
  • Saccules:
    • Small outpouchings of the bladder wall, often due to increased intravesical pressure from long standing obstruction.
  • Causes:
    • Most commonly associated with chronic BPH but can also be seen in conditions causing sustained obstruction or increased intravesical pressure.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Indicates chronic bladder outlet obstruction, which may lead to complications like recurrent UTIs, bladder stones, and chronic kidney disease if untreated.
  • Management:
    • Address underlying obstruction (e.g., medication or surgery for BPH). Regular monitoring for complications such as urinary retention or infection.

Option A: Chronic bladder outlet obstruction is Correct. Trabeculation and saccules are characteristic findings of bladder wall changes due to chronic obstruction, often from BPH.

Option B: Acute cystitis is Incorrect. Acute cystitis typically shows mucosal inflammation but does not cause trabeculation or saccules.

Option C: Bladder cancer is Incorrect. While it may cause mucosal irregularities and masses, it does not typically result in trabeculation or saccules.

Option D: Neurogenic bladder is Incorrect. Although it can lead to changes in bladder function, trabeculation and saccules are more specific to chronic obstruction.

Key Takeaway:

  • Trabeculation and saccules are signs of chronic bladder outlet obstruction.
  • Common in patients with longstanding BPH.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and episodes of hematuria. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Bladder Stones

Bladder stones are hard deposits that form in the bladder when minerals in urine crystallise. They are often associated with chronic urinary retention and stasis, which occurs when urine is not emptied completely.

Common Causes

  • BPH: Benign prostatic hyperplasia is a common cause of bladder stones due to the obstruction it causes, leading to incomplete emptying of the bladder.
  • Neurogenic bladder: Conditions that affect the nerves controlling the bladder can lead to urinary retention and stone formation.
  • Foreign bodies
  • Chronic infections

Symptoms

  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Hematuria: Blood in the urine
  • Suprapubic pain: Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Obstructive symptoms: Difficulty urinating, weak stream, or urinary retention

Diagnosis

  • Imaging: Ultrasound, X-ray, or CT scan can be used to visualise bladder stones.
  • Cystoscopy: A procedure that allows direct visualisation of the bladder can confirm the presence of stones.

Management

  • Endoscopic removal: Bladder stones can often be removed using a cystoscopy procedure.
  • Addressing the underlying cause: Treating the underlying condition, such as BPH or neurogenic bladder, is essential to prevent recurrence of bladder stones.

Option A: Chronic dehydration is Incorrect. While dehydration can contribute to stone formation, it is less commonly the primary cause of bladder stones compared to obstruction.

Option B: Urethral stricture is Incorrect. Strictures may cause bladder stones, but BPH is a more common cause of obstruction in older men, leading to stone formation.

Option C: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is Correct. BPH can cause bladder outlet obstruction, leading to urinary stasis and stone formation.

Option D: High oxalate diet is Incorrect. A high oxalate diet is more closely associated with kidney stones, not specifically bladder stones.

Key Takeaway:

  • BPH is a common cause of bladder stones due to urinary stasis.
  • Imaging or cystoscopy is required to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65 year old smoker presents with painless hematuria. Cystoscopy reveals multiple papillary lesions in the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Papillary Bladder Tumours

Transitional Cell Carcinoma (TCC) is the most common type of bladder cancer, arising from the urothelial cells that line the bladder.

Risk Factors

  • Smoking: The most significant risk factor.
  • Occupational exposure: To chemicals like aniline dyes and aromatic amines.
  • Chronic bladder irritation: From conditions like bladder stones or infections.
  • Prior radiation therapy

Symptoms

  • Painless hematuria: The most common presenting symptom.
  • Frequency: Frequent urination.
  • Urgency: A sudden, strong urge to urinate.
  • Dysuria: Painful urination.

Diagnosis

  • Cystoscopy: A procedure that allows direct visualisation of the bladder.
  • Biopsy: A tissue sample is taken for examination to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Imaging: CT urogram may be used to assess the extent of the tumour.

Treatment

  • TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumour): A minimally invasive procedure to remove the tumour.
  • Intravesical therapy: Medication is instilled directly into the bladder to treat residual tumour cells.
  • Cystectomy: Removal of the bladder.
  • Systemic chemotherapy: For advanced-stage cancer.

Option A: Bladder calculi is Incorrect. Stones may cause hematuria but do not present as papillary lesions.

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is Correct. TCC is the most common type of bladder cancer, often presenting as papillary lesions on cystoscopy.

Option C: Chronic cystitis is Incorrect. While chronic inflammation can cause thickening of the bladder wall, it does not typically result in papillary growths.

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma is Incorrect. SCC is less common and usually associated with chronic irritation or infection, presenting as more invasive, non papillary lesions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Painless hematuria in a smoker is highly suggestive of TCC.
  • Cystoscopy and biopsy are essential for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which type of renal stone is most commonly associated with infection?
questions.solution:
Option A: Calcium oxalate is Incorrect. These are the most common type of kidney stones but are not directly associated with infection.

Option B: Uric acid is Incorrect. Uric acid stones are related to high uric acid levels and acidic urine, not infections.

Option C: Struvite is Correct. Struvite stones are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate and are associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease producing bacteria.

Option D: Cystine is Incorrect. Cystine stones are caused by a genetic disorder leading to cystinuria and are not related to infection.

Key Takeaway:

  • Struvite stones are associated with infection by urease producing organisms.
  • Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of renal stones.

questions.text: Which type of renal stone is typically radiolucent and not visible on plain X Ray?
questions.solution:
Radiolucent and Radiopaque Renal Stones

  • Radiolucent Stones: Uric acid stones do not appear on plain X Ray. Diagnosis requires ultrasound or CT.
  • Radiopaque Stones: Calcium oxalate, struvite, and calcium phosphate stones are visible on Xray.

Diagnostic Approach: Noncontrast CT is the gold standard for detecting all types of stones.

Option A: Calcium oxalate is Incorrect. These stones are radiopaque and usually visible on Xray.

Option B: Struvite is Incorrect. Struvite stones are radiopaque due to their magnesium and phosphate content.

Option C: Uric acid is Correct. Uric acid stones are radiolucent and not visible on plain X Ray but can be seen on ultrasound or CT scan.

Option D: Calcium phosphate is Incorrect. These stones are radiopaque and visible on plain X Ray.

Key Takeaway:

  • Uric acid stones are radiolucent and require ultrasound or CT for detection.Most other stone types are radiopaque and visible on Xray.

questions.text: A 65 year old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and postvoid dribbling. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bladder Diverticulum

  • Outpouchings of the bladder mucosa through the muscular wall.
  • Types:
    • Congenital Diverticula: Present at birth; usually single and large.
    • Acquired Diverticula: Develop due to increased intravesical pressure, often secondary to bladder outlet obstruction (e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia); usually multiple and smaller.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Asymptomatic in many cases.
    • Symptoms may include urinary tract infections (UTIs), hematuria, and difficulty voiding.
    • May cause bladder stones or urinary retention.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound: Initial imaging to detect diverticula.
    • Cystoscopy: Direct visualisation and assessment of the diverticulum.
    • Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG): Evaluates the size and shape of the diverticula and checks for reflux.
    • CT Scan: Provides detailed anatomy, especially for surgical planning.
  • Management:
    • Observation: For asymptomatic cases without complications.
    • Surgical Intervention: Indicated for recurrent UTIs, stones, significant symptoms, or large diverticula. Options include open diverticulectomy or minimally invasive laparoscopic techniques.
  • Complications:
    • Infection: Recurrent UTIs due to urine stasis.
    • Bladder Stones: Formation within the diverticulum.
    • Diverticular Rupture: Rare but can occur.
    • Malignancy: Rare risk of developing cancer within the diverticulum.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Bladder diverticulum: Correct. Diverticula are saclike outpouching of the bladder wall, often due to chronic bladder outlet obstruction.

Option B. Urethral stricture: Incorrect. Strictures cause narrowing, not outpouching, and lead to obstructive symptoms.

Option C. Vesicoureteral reflux: Incorrect. Reflux involves backward urine flow into the ureters, not bladder wall outpouching.

Option D. Bladder cancer: Incorrect. Cancer presents as a mass, not as a diverticulum.

Key Points:

  • Bladder diverticula are outpouchings of the bladder lining, commonly caused by increased bladder pressure.
  • Asymptomatic diverticula can be monitored, while symptomatic or complicated cases may require surgery.

questions.text: A newborn presents with exposed bladder mucosa and epispadias. Which condition does this most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
Bladder Exstrophy

  • Congenital defect with bladder exposed on the abdominal wall.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Failure of the cloacal membrane to close during embryonic development.
    • Associated with abnormalities of the bony pelvis and genitalia.
  • Features:
    • Visible bladder mucosa on the abdominal wall, typically red and moist.
    • Continuous leakage of urine from the exposed bladder.
    • Widened pubic symphysis and abnormal external genitalia.
    • Umbilicus is often located below the normal position.
  • Complications:
    • Recurrent UTIs, renal impairment, increased cancer risk.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination at birth.
  • Management:
    • Initial Management: Keep the bladder moist and covered with a plastic film; avoid infection.
    • Surgical Repair:
      • Bilateral iliac osteotomies with bladder exstrophy and abdominal wall closure in the neonatal period,
      • Epispadias repair and phallic reconstruction at 6 months to 1 year of age
      • Finally bladder neck reconstruction and bilateral ureteric reimplantation (to treat VUR) at age 5-7 years.

Key Points:

  • Bladder exstrophy is a congenital anomaly with an exposed bladder on the abdominal surface.
  • Surgical management involves multiple stages to close the bladder, repair associated defects, and achieve urinary continence.

questions.text: A 55 year old woman leaks urine when she coughs or sneezes. What type of urinary incontinence is this?
questions.solution:
Types of Urinary Incontinence

  • Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) refers to involuntary leakage on effort or exertion, or on sneezing or coughing.
  • Urgency urinary incontinence (UUI) refers to involuntary leakage accompanied by or immediately preceded by urgency (a sudden compelling desire to pass urine which is difficult to defer).
  • Mixed urinary incontinence (MUI) refers to involuntary leakage associated with urgency and also with exertion, sneezing or coughing.
  • Continuous urinary incontinence refers to the continuous involuntary loss of urine (this warrants investigation for anatomical pathology such as ectopic ureter or fistula from the ureter, bladder or urethra to the vagina).
  • Nocturnal enuresis refers to involuntary leakage during sleep.
  • Incontinence associated with chronic urinary retention refers to leakage in conditions where the bladder does not empty completely.
  • Functional incontinence refers to leakage that results from an inability to reach the toilet because of cognitive, functional or mobility impairments in the presence of an intact LUT system.
  • Overactive bladder (OAB) refers to symptoms of urgency with or without UUI, usually with frequency and nocturia. It can be neurogenic (secondary to a neurological condition) or idiopathic (without identifiable cause).

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Urge incontinence: Incorrect. Urge incontinence involves a sudden urge to void.

Option B. Stress incontinence: Correct. Stress incontinence occurs with increased abdominal pressure during physical activity.

Option C. Overflow incontinence: Incorrect. Overflow involves constant dribbling due to bladder overdistension.

Option D. Functional incontinence: Incorrect. Functional incontinence results from physical or cognitive barriers to bathroom access.

Key Points:

  • Stress incontinence is common in women due to pelvic floor weakness.
  • Triggered by activities that increase abdominal pressure.

questions.text: A 50 year old female complains of continuous urine leakage after hysterectomy. The first swab in a three swab test shows dye stained urine. What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
Three Swab Test

  • Purpose: Diagnose urinary fistulas, especially postsurgical.
  • Procedure: Dye instilled into the bladder; swabs placed in the vagina detect leakage.
  • Three numbered gauze swabs are placed into the vagina, with swab number 1 placed most proximally, swab number 2 in the middle and swab number 3 most distal in the vagina.
  • A blue dye is then instilled into the bladder through a catheter, and the catheter removed.
  • Blue staining of swab 1 or 2 suggests VVF
  • whereas blue staining of swab 3 suggests a urethra vaginal fistula or SUI.
  • If swab 1 is wet but not stained blue, this suggests the presence of a ureterovaginal fistula.
  • Management: Surgical repair to restore urinary continence

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Urethrovaginal fistula: Incorrect. Involves urethravagina connection, different presentation.

Option B. Vesicovaginal fistula: Correct. Indicates direct bladder to vagina communication.

Option C. Ureterovaginal fistula: Incorrect. Involves uretervagina connection, often leads to continuous urine flow unrelated to bladder filling.

Option D. Normal result: Incorrect. Dye presence indicates an abnormal fistula.

Key Points:

The three swab test diagnoses vesicovaginal fistulas.

choices.text: Routine use for all hospitalised patients
Monitoring urine output in critically ill patients
Long Term management of urinary incontinence
To prevent bedwetting in older adults

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct indication for using a urinary catheter?
questions.solution:
Indications for Catheterization

Urethral catheterisation

  1. Aseptic technique - hand washing, sterile gloves, sterile catheter pack.
  2. Clean urethral meatus with antiseptic solution.
  3. Instil lidocaine gel into the urethra and hold it for 2-3 minutes. In men, the penis should be held perpendicular and taught. In women, the labia should be held apart to provide adequate exposure of the urethral meatus.
  4. The catheter should be inserted as far as the 'hilt' of the catheter and should pass freely (the type of catheter is dependent on the indication).
  5. The position in the bladder is confirmed with the drainage of clear urine and the balloon should be inflated with 10 mL of sterile water. The catheter bag should then be attached.
  6. Details regarding the type and size of catheter, and residual volume, should be clearly recorded.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Routine use for all hospitalised patients: Incorrect. Indiscriminate use increases infection risk and is not recommended.

Option B. Monitoring urine output in critically ill patients: Correct. Accurate measurement of urine output is crucial in critically ill patients to monitor fluid balance.

Option C. Long Term management of urinary incontinence: Incorrect. Catheters should not be used for long term incontinence management due to infection risks.

Option D. To prevent bedwetting in older adults: Incorrect. Catheters are not used for this purpose; other management strategies are preferable.

Key Points:

  • Catheterization is essential for accurate urine output monitoring in critically ill patients.
  • Routine use should be avoided to minimise infection risks.

questions.text:
Match the French size of the catheter to its corresponding diameter:
1. 12 Fr
2. 16 Fr
3. 24 Fr

A. 4.0 mm
B. 8.0 mm
C. 5.3 mm
questions.solution:
1 → A. 4.0 mm

2 → C. 5.3 mm

3 → B. 8.0 mm

French Scale for Catheter Size

  • French Scale: Measures catheter diameter; 1 Fr = 0.3 mm.
  • The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter,
  • The standard catheter size for uncomplicated urethral catheterisation in women is 12Fr or 14Fr, and in men 16Fr.
  • In patients with urethral stricture, a smaller size catheter should be considered.
  • In cases of haematuria with 'clot retention', a 22Fr catheter is typically used to aid drainage of thick clots.
  • Coude tip catheters have a curved tip to allow easier passage past an enlarged prostate.
  • Number of channels Single-channel catheters consist of a single drainage channel only and are used for CISC as these catheters do not require an indwelling retention mechanism.
  • The Foley catheter consists of two channels - a drainage channel and a channel for inflation of a balloon at the tip, which allows the catheter to be retained in the bladder. This is the standard catheter used for uncomplicated cases of urinary retention.
  • The 'three-way' catheter has an additional channel for bladder irrigation and is used for patients with haematuria and 'clot retention' and following transurethral prostate or bladder surgery.

Explanation of Matching:

  • 12 Fr: Corresponds to 4.0 mm diameter.
  • 16 Fr: Corresponds to 5.3 mm diameter.
  • 24 Fr: Corresponds to 8.0 mm diameter

Key Points:

  • The French scale converts catheter size to diameter in mm.
  • 1 Fr equals 0.3 mm in diameter.

choices.text: It is a non-invasive method using shock waves.
It is primarily used for stones larger than 5 cm.
It is ineffective for stones in the ureter.

questions.text: Acoustic pulse is used for lithotripsy to break kidney and bladder stones. Which of the following statements about this technique is true?
questions.solution:
ESWL

  • High-energy shock waves are generated outside the body and focused on the stone using imaging guidance (X-ray or ultrasound). These shock waves break the stone into smaller pieces.
  • Indications:
    • Stones up to 2 cm in size, typically located in the kidney or upper ureter.
  • Advantages: Noninvasive, less need for surgery, quick recovery.
  • Contraindications:
    • Pregnancy (risk to the foetus).
    • Uncontrolled bleeding disorders.
    • Severe skeletal abnormalities or obesity that prevents proper positioning.
    • Presence of untreated urinary tract infections.
  • Procedure:
    • Performed under sedation or anaesthesia.
    • Patient positioned on a cushion to allow the transmission of shock waves.
    • Real-time imaging (X-ray or ultrasound) is used to target the stone.
    • The procedure typically lasts about 30-60 minutes.
  • Complications:
    • Hematuria: Common and usually resolves on its own.
    • Pain: Can occur due to passing stone fragments.
    • Infection: Rare but possible, may require antibiotics.
    • Incomplete Fragmentation: Some stones may not break completely, necessitating additional treatment.
  • Post-Procedure Care: Patients are advised to drink plenty of water to help pass the stone fragments.
  • Limitations: Less effective for very large stones or those in the lower ureter.

Key Points:

  • Lithotripsy is noninvasive and uses shock waves.
  • It is suitable for stones up to 2 cm.

choices.text: It is the leading cause of bladder cancer in developed countries.
It primarily causes adenocarcinoma of the bladder.
It is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
It is unrelated to bladder cancer risk.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the relationship between given organism and bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Schistosoma Haematobium

  • Pathology: Chronic inflammation leads to squamous metaplasia in the bladder.
  • Cancer Risk: Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
  • The parasite penetrates the skin and travels to the liver (as schistosomula), where it matures. Adult trematodes migrate to vesical veins and lay eggs (containing miracidium larvae), which leave the body by penetrating the bladder and entering the urine.
  • The active phase is when eggs are actively being laid, whereas the inactive phase is when the adult has died but there is an ongoing reaction to the remaining eggs. At the time of infection, a local inflammatory response leads to irritation of the skin ('swimmer's itch').
  • Acute fever (Katayama fever) may ensue at the onset of egg laying (3 weeks to 4 months after infection) with fever, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and eosinophilia. When the eggs are deposited in the bladder, the typical bladder
  • Symptoms:
    • Intermittent painless haematuria and terminal dysuria Chronic infection can lead to a small, contracted, fibrotic bladder similar to that seen with tuberculous cystitis.
    • Patients are at increased risk of developing ureteric strictures, urethral strictures and squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
  • Investigation with midday (to coincide with the time of maximum egg shedding) urine microscopy may show characteristic eggs with terminal spines
  • Cystoscopy may show characteristic 'sandy patches' at the trigone (due to calcified dead ova with degeneration of the overlying urothelium), ulceration or papillomas. In advanced cases, carcinoma may be present. Bladder or rectal biopsies may identify eggs.
  • Treatment is with praziquantel 20 mg/kg in two divided doses 4-6 hours apart.

Key Points:

  • Schistosoma haematobium infection is linked to squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Common in regions where schistosomiasis is endemic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest known risk factor for developing bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Risk Factors for Bladder Cancer

  • Smoking: The leading cause of bladder cancer due to carcinogens excreted in urine.
  • Occupational Exposures: Chemical exposures (e.g., aromatic amines) in industries such as dye, rubber, and leather manufacturing.
  • Schistosomiasis: Endemic in some regions, leading to squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Chronic Inflammation: Chronic urinary tract infections, indwelling catheters, and bladder stones.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Chronic urinary tract infections: Incorrect. While recurrent infections can be a risk factor, especially for squamous cell carcinoma, smoking is a more significant risk factor.

Option B. Exposure to schistosomiasis: Incorrect. Schistosomiasis is linked to squamous cell carcinoma but is less prevalent globally compared to smoking.

Option C. Smoking: Correct. Smoking is the most significant risk factor for bladder cancer, particularly transitional cell carcinoma, due to the carcinogenic substances in tobacco.

Option D. Occupational exposure to asbestos: Incorrect. While certain occupational exposures increase bladder cancer risk, asbestos is more commonly linked to lung cancers and mesothelioma.

Key Points:

Smoking is the strongest risk factor for bladder cancer.

Occupational and parasitic exposures also increase risk.

questions.text: Which histological subtype is most common in bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Histological Subtypes of Bladder Cancer

  • Transitional Cell Carcinoma (TCC): Most common, comprising about 90% of bladder cancers. Originates from urothelial cells.
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Linked to chronic irritation (e.g., schistosomiasis, catheter use).
  • Adenocarcinoma: Rare, can develop from urachal remnants or glandular metaplasia.
  • Small Cell Carcinoma: Rare, aggressive, and typically presents at an advanced stage.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect. This type is less common and associated with chronic irritation and schistosomiasis.

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Incorrect. Adenocarcinomas are rare and may arise from urachal remnants or metaplasia.

Option C. Transitional cell carcinoma: Correct. Transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) is the most common type, arising from the urothelial lining of the bladder.

Option D. Small cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Small cell carcinoma is rare and typically has a more aggressive course.

Key Points:

  • Transitional cell carcinoma is the most common bladder cancer type.
  • Other types include squamous cell and adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with bladder cancer that invades the muscularis propria inner layer. What is the TNM stage of this tumour?
questions.solution:
TNM Staging of Bladder Cancer

  • T1: Invasion into lamina propria, not muscularis propria.
  • T2: Invasion into muscularis propria; divided into:
    • T2a: Superficial muscularis propria (inner half).
    • T2b: Deep muscularis propria (outer half).
  • T3: Invasion into perivesical tissue.
  • T4: Invasion into adjacent structures (prostate, uterus, vagina, pelvic wall).

Key Points:

  • T2a bladder cancer invades the superficial layer of muscularis propria.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common long-term complication of urinary diversion?
questions.solution:
Urinary Diversion

A surgical procedure to reroute the normal flow of urine due to bladder dysfunction, disease, or removal.

Indications:

  • Bladder cancer (following cystectomy).
  • Severe bladder dysfunction (neurogenic bladder).
  • Chronic bladder infections or fistulas.
  • Trauma or congenital anomalies.

Types of Urinary Diversion:

Ileal Conduit:

  • Most common form of diversion.
  • A segment of the ileum is used to create a conduit between the ureters and an external stoma.
  • Urine drains into an external appliance (urostomy bag).

Orthotopic Neobladder:

  • A reservoir is created from the intestine and connected to the urethra.
  • Allows for near-normal urination without the need for a stoma.
  • Suitable for patients without urethral disease and with good renal function.

Continent Cutaneous Diversion (Indiana Pouch):

  • Intestinal segment forms a reservoir with a stoma on the abdomen.
  • Patient catheterizes the stoma to empty the bladder, providing continence.

Complications:

  • Metabolic Acidosis: Common due to bicarbonate loss in bowel segment diversions (e.g., ileal conduit).
  • Infections: Urinary tract infections due to stasis and bacterial colonisation.
  • Bowel Complications: Obstruction, fistula formation, or absorption issues.
  • Electrolyte Imbalances: Altered absorption can lead to imbalances, especially in diversions using the intestine.
  • Rarely adenocarcinoma (5%)

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Incorrect. This is a potential surgical risk but not a common long term complication of urinary diversion.

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Correct. Urinary diversion can lead to metabolic acidosis due to bicarbonate loss through the bowel segment used for urine passage.

Option C. Hypercalcemia: Incorrect. Urinary diversions do not typically cause hypercalcemia.

Option D. Peripheral neuropathy: Incorrect. Neuropathy is not a common complication related to urinary diversions.

Key Points:

Metabolic acidosis is a complication of urinary diversion due to bicarbonate loss.

questions.text: A patient presents after a motor vehicle accident with suspected bladder injury. Cystography shown. What type of bladder injury is this?
questions.solution:
Bladder Trauma: Intraperitoneal vs. Extraperitoneal

  • Extraperitoneal Rupture: Commonly caused by pelvic fractures, with contrast leakage around the bladder in the pelvic cavity.
  • Intraperitoneal Rupture: Typically caused by a direct blow to a full bladder, showing contrast in the peritoneal cavity.
  • Diagnosis: Cystography is the imaging modality of choice.
  • Management: Extraperitoneal injuries usually managed conservatively; intraperitoneal injuries require surgical repair.

Key Points:

  • Extraperitoneal rupture shows contrast confined to the pelvic area.
  • Intraperitoneal rupture requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: A bladder injury involves a full thickness tear(1.5 cm) of the bladder wall without involvement of the peritoneum. How is this graded?
questions.solution:
Grading of Bladder Trauma

  • Bladder trauma can be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal
  • Extraperitoneal injury can be managed with indwelling catheterisation for 10-14 days
  • Intraperitoneal injury most often requires laparotomy and repair of the bladder defect

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Grade 1: Incorrect. Grade 1 involves contusion or hematoma without tear.

Option B. Grade 2: Correct. Grade 2 involves a partial tear, but the bladder wall is still intact.

Option C. Grade 3 Incorrect. Grade 3 bladder trauma involves a full thickness tear of the bladder wall with/without peritoneal involvement.

Option D. Grade 4: Incorrect. >2cm intraperitoneal bladder wall laceration.

Key Points:

  • Extraperitoneal injury can be managed with indwelling catheterisation for 10-14 days
  • Intraperitoneal injury most often requires laparotomy and repair of the bladder defect.

questions.text: A 3 year old boy presents with a persistent umbilical discharge that is mucopurulent and occasionally blood-tinged. Physical examination reveals a small opening at the umbilicus. An ultrasound shows a midline fluid filled structure extending from the umbilicus towards the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Urachal Anomalies

  • Urachal anomalies are congenital malformations resulting from incomplete obliteration of the urachus, a tubular structure that connects the bladder to the umbilicus during foetal development.

Types of Urachal Anomalies:

  • Patent Urachus: Persistent tubular connection between the bladder and umbilicus, leading to continuous urine leakage from the umbilicus.
  • Urachal Cyst: A fluid filled cyst forms anywhere along the urachal tract due to partial obliteration; it does not communicate with the bladder or umbilicus.
  • Urachal Sinus: The umbilical end of the urachus remains open, leading to a blind ending sinus tract with umbilical discharge.
  • Urachal Diverticulum: The bladder end remains open, creating a diverticulum that protrudes from the bladder wall.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Patent Urachus: Persistent clear, mucopurulent, or blood tinged umbilical discharge; risk of infection.
  • Urachal Cyst: Asymptomatic until infected; presents with localised pain, fever, and signs of infection.
  • Urachal Sinus: Umbilical discharge, localised erythema, and tenderness around the umbilicus.
  • Urachal Diverticulum: Usually asymptomatic but may present with urinary tract infections or lower abdominal pain.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging: Ultrasound is the initial imaging modality to identify fluid filled structures along the midline. Further evaluation may include voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), CT, or MRI for better anatomical detail.
  • Cystoscopy: Can help visualise the bladder end of a patent urachus or diverticulum.

Management:

  • Conservative Management: For asymptomatic urachal cysts or diverticula, watchful waiting with regular monitoring.
  • Surgical Intervention: Indicated for symptomatic cases (e.g., patent urachus, infected cyst, recurrent infection). Complete excision of the urachal remnant and any associated structures (e.g., umbilicus) to prevent recurrence and potential malignancy.
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics for infected cysts or sinuses prior to surgical intervention.

Complications:

  • Infection: Most common complication, presenting as abscess formation.
  • Malignancy: Rare but potential risk of adenocarcinoma developing in longstanding untreated urachal remnants.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Omphalomesenteric duct remnant: Incorrect. This remnant would present with a different type of umbilical discharge, often related to the gastrointestinal tract, and may include feculent material.

Option B. Patent urachus: Correct. A patent urachus is characterised by persistent communication between the bladder and the umbilicus, leading to mucopurulent discharge. The presence of a midline fluid filled structure extending from the umbilicus to the bladder on imaging supports this diagnosis.

Option C. Meckel's diverticulum: Incorrect. Meckel's diverticulum typically presents with gastrointestinal bleeding, pain, or signs of bowel obstruction, not umbilical discharge.

Option D. Urachal cyst: Incorrect. A urachal cyst usually presents as a noncommunicating, fluid filled cyst along the urachal tract, not directly with umbilical discharge.

Key Points:

  • Patent urachus presents with umbilical discharge and a connection to the bladder.
  • Urachal cysts may become symptomatic when infected, requiring surgical excision.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is classified as a storage symptom in lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)?
questions.solution:
Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms (LUTS)

  • LUTS can be described as:
  • Voiding:
    • hesitancy (worsened if the bladder is very full);
    • poor flow (unimproved by straining)
    • intermittent stream - stops and starts;
    • dribbling (including after micturition);
    • sensation of poor bladder emptying;
    • episodes of near retention.
  • Storage:
    • frequency;
    • nocturia;
    • urgency;
    • urge incontinence;
    • nocturnal incontinence (enuresis).
  • Causes: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), bladder dysfunction, urethral stricture.
  • Assessment: Symptom score questionnaires, uroflowmetry, and postvoid residual volume measurement.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hesitancy: Incorrect. Hesitancy is a voiding symptom, indicating difficulty initiating urination.

Option B. Straining: Incorrect. Straining is a voiding symptom, often due to bladder outlet obstruction.

Option C. Nocturia: Correct. Nocturia is a storage symptom, characterised by waking up at night to urinate.

Option D. Weak stream: Incorrect. Weak stream is a voiding symptom, associated with reduced flow rate due to obstruction.

Key Points:

  • Nocturia is a storage symptom of LUTS.
  • Voiding symptoms include hesitancy and weak stream.

choices.text: Prolonged time to reach peak flow rate

questions.text: In a patient suspected of bladder outlet obstruction, what finding on uroflowmetry is most indicative of obstruction?
questions.solution:
Uroflowmetry in Bladder Outlet Obstruction

  • Purpose: Measures urine flow rate to assess bladder function and detect obstructions.
  • Urodynamically proven BOO may result from:
    • BPH;
    • bladder neck stenosis;
    • bladder neck dyssynergia or functional bladder neck obstruction;
    • bladder neck hypertrophy;
    • prostate cancer;
    • urethral stricture;
    • functional obstruction due to neuropathic conditions.
  • The primary effects of BOO on the bladder are as follows:
    • Urinary flow rates decrease: for a voided volume >200 mL, a peak flow rate of >15 mL/s is normal
    • one of 10-15 mL/s is equivocal;
    • one <10 mL/s is low
  • Voiding pressures increase:
    • pressures >80 cmH2 O are high
    • pressures between 60 and 80 cm H2O are equivocal;
    • pressures <60 cmH2O are normal.
  • Acute retention of urine is sometimes the first symptom of BOO.
  • Chronic retention. In patients in whom the residual volume is >250 mL or so the tension in the bladder wall increases owing to the combination of a large volume of residual urine and increased resting and filling bladder pressures (a condition known as high-pressure chronic retention).
  • Uses: Commonly used in evaluating BPH, urethral strictures, and other obstructive uropathies.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Peak flow rate > 15 mL/sec: Incorrect. A peak flow rate above 15 mL/sec typically indicates no significant obstruction.

Option B. Prolonged time to reach peak flow rate: Correct. This is a common finding in bladder outlet obstruction due to increased resistance.

Option C. Residual urine volume of 0 mL: Incorrect. No residual urine suggests effective bladder emptying.

Option D. Total voided volume < 100 mL: Incorrect. This finding might indicate reduced bladder capacity but not specifically obstruction

Key Points:

  • Normal Findings: Peak flow rate >15 mL/sec; quick time to peak flow.
  • Obstruction Indicators: Prolonged time to reach peak flow, reduced peak flow rate (<10 mL/sec), increased post void residual urine.

questions.text: 66 year old male presents with LUTS. Which investigation is most commonly used as the first step in evaluating a man with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)?
questions.solution:
Investigations in LUTS

  • Firstline Investigations: DRE to assess prostate size, urinalysis to rule out infection, and serum PSA if prostate cancer is suspected.
  • In benign enlargement, the posterior surface of the prostate is smooth, convex and typically elastic, but the fibrous element may give the prostate a fIrm consistency. The rectal mucosa can be made to move over the prostate.
  • Rectal examination can detect nodules within the prostate and advanced disease. Irregular induration, characteristically stony hard in part or in the whole of the gland (with obliteration of the median sulcus), suggests carcinoma.
  • if there is a considerable amount of residual urine present, it pushes the prostate downwards, making it appear larger than it is. It is not always possible to examine the cranial extreme of the very large prostate per rectum. An inability to get to the prostate base implies a volume of at least 50 mL.
  • Further Tests: Uroflowmetry, postvoid residual volume, and ultrasound if indicated.
  • Purpose: To distinguish between benign conditions (e.g., BPH) and malignancy.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Prostate biopsy: Incorrect. Biopsy is reserved for cases with a high suspicion of prostate cancer.

Option B. Uroflowmetry: Incorrect. Uroflowmetry assesses urine flow but is not typically the first step.

Option C. Digital rectal examination (DRE): Correct. DRE is a first line examination to evaluate prostate size and consistency.

Option D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): Incorrect. MRI is not routinely used for initial evaluation of LUTS.

Key Points:

DRE is commonly used first to evaluate prostate size in men with LUTS.

Uroflowmetry and PSA testing are used for further assessment.
